STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
October 31, 2025
Renee Adorjan
Washtenaw County DHHS
22 Center ST,
YPSILANTI, MI, 48198-5707
Re: License #: CP810201490
Dear Ms. Adorjan:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
9/28/2025; and an Exit conference was held with the agency on 10/15/2025. Due to the
violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager Jessica VandenHeuvel at 616-204-6992.
.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Lonia Perry Calloway, Licensing Consultant
Enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP810201490
Licensee Group Organization: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Designee: Demetrius LuJuan Starling
Chief Administrator: Renee Adorjan
Name of Agency: WASHTENAW COUNTY DHHS
Agency Address: 22 CENTER ST
YPSILANTI, MI 48198-5707
Agency Telephone #: 7344818364
Original Issuance Date: 10/05/1994
Service Types: Certify foster homes for license, Evaluate
Applicants for adoption, Place children for
adoption, Place children in foster home,
Supervise Independent Living
1

II. METHODS OF INSPECTION
A. Consultant
Date(s) of On-site Inspection: 9/8/25, 9/9/25
Total No. Of No. of
Records Records
Reviewed

in foster care since last inspection 0 0
Incidents of substantiated corporal punishment in foster care
since last inspection 0 0

(placement in foster homes, parental home,
relative homes, CCI, hospital, etc.) 47 6

since the last inspection 3 3

B. Analyst

Unlicensed relative homes 8 3

Relatives 3
Others (identify person interviewed by role) 0
III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
(5) If an agency is no longer providing services to the child in a foster home, then
both the following must be documented before a change in placement:
(a) A summary of the services provided during care up to the time of the change in
placement and the needs that remain to be met.
In one of four closed foster child records reviewed the record did not show
documentation of a summary of services provided during care up to the change and
the needs that remain to be met.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal 2024, CAP approved 11/6/2024.
Interim 2023, CAP approved 12/11/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
(5) If an agency is no longer providing services to the child in a foster home, then
both the following must be documented before a change in placement:
(b) Provision for any continuing services.
In one of four closed foster child records reviewed the record did not show
documentation as to whether there were provisions for any continuing services.
2

Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal 2024, CAP approved 11/6/2024.
Interim 2023, CAP approved 12/11/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must, include all the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows, unless a greater frequency is
medically indicated:
(i) A comprehensive medical examination, including a behavioral/mental health and
trauma screening, within 30 calendar days from the date the child entered into an
out-of-home placement, regardless of the date of the last physical examination.
One of six open foster child records reviewed showed that the child's medical due
by 6/8/2025 was completed late on 6/27/2025, Additionally, the child's trauma
screening due by 6/8/2025 was completed late on 8/12/2025.
Repeat Violation Established:
Interim 2023, CAP approved 12/11/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy must, include all the following:
(d) Current immunizations for each child as required by section 5111 of the public
health code, 1978 PA 368, MCL 333.5111. All the following apply:
(iii) If documentation of immunization or a copy of the waiver is unavailable, then
immunizations must begin within 30 calendar days of placement.
One of eight open foster child records reviewed showed the child's
DTP/DTaP/DT/Td/Tdap immunization expired 7/5/2025; and an updated
immunization was not documented.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal 2024, CAP approved 11/6/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(2) An agency shall maintain a file documentation from the medical or dental
provider of all medical and dental care received by a foster child.
3

Two of six open foster child records reviewed showed documentation of one child’s
3/18/2025 dental exam, and the second child's 6/13/2024 dental exam and
6/27/2025 medical exam were not by way of the respective service provider.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all the following information before
the placement or replacement of a child:
(c) Available known information about the child's health.
Two of six open foster child records reviewed did not show proof that information
about the child's health was provided prior to placement, as required by the rule.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal 2024, CAP approved 11/6/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all the following information before
the placement or replacement of a child:
(d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the child.
Two of six open foster child records reviewed did not show proof that the caregiver
was provided information as to whether the child had a history of abuse or neglect,
prior to placement, as required by the rule.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal 2024, CAP approved 11/6/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all the following information before
the placement or replacement of a child:
(e) All known emotional and psychological factors relating to the care of the child.
Two of six open foster child records reviewed did not show proof that the caregiver
was provided with all known emotional and psychological information on the child
prior to placement, as required by the rule.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal 2024, CAP approved 11/6/2024.
4

CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all the following information before
the placement or replacement of a child:
(f) All known behaviors of the child.
Two of six open foster child records reviewed did not show proof that the caregiver
was provided information about any behaviors for the child prior to placement, as
required by the rule.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal 2024, CAP approved 11/6/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all the following information before
the placement or replacement of a child:
(g) Circumstances necessitating placement or replacement of the child.
Two of six open foster child records reviewed did not show proof that the caregiver
was provided information about the circumstances leading to the child's placement
prior to placement, as required by the rule.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal 2024, CAP approved 11/6/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(5) An agency shall involve the child's parent or parents and the foster parents in the
development of service plans to enable the parent or parents and foster parents to
understand the plan for the child and the parents' and the foster parent's role in
assisting the agency in carrying out the plan. An agency shall give a copy to and
review the parent-agency treatment plan with the parent or parents and foster
parents. The agency must inform the parent or parents and foster parent that the
information in the parent-agency treatment plan and any other information about the
child and the child's family is confidential.
Four of six open foster child records reviewed did not show that all treatment plans
were signed and or were signed timely by all parties.
Repeat Violation Established:
5

Interim 2023, CAP approved 12/11/2023, cited under FOM 722-8D.
CPA Rule 400.12419 Initial service plans.
(1) The initial service plan, as required in R 400.12418(2)(a), must include all the
following information:
(c) Assessment of the placement selection criteria as required under R
400.12404(4).
In two of six open foster child records reviewed showed the child's initial service
plan did not document the placement selection criteria.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal 2024, CAP approved 11/6/2024.
Interim 2023, CAP approved 12/11/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12422 Foster care case record.
(3) The record must contain all the following information:
(g) A photograph taken at least annually.
Two of four closed child records reviewed did not show documentation of a photo
taken annually, as required by the rule.
CPA Rule 400.12502 Program statement.
(2) An agency shall give a copy of the program statement to a youth before
placement in independent living.
One of three open independent living youth records reviewed did not show
documentation that the youth was provided with a copy of the agency’s program
statement at or prior to his 3/28/2025 placement.
CPA Rule 400.12503 Policy and procedures.
(3) An agency shall provide a youth in independent living with a copy of the
agency's policies and procedures required by this rule.
One of three open independent living youth records reviewed did not show
documentation that the youth was provided with a copy of the agency's policies and
procedures at or prior to his 3/28/2025 placement.
6

CPA Rule 400.12505 Supervision.
(2) An agency shall provide the following minimum supervision:
(a) Face-to-face contact between the social service worker and the youth in
independent living at least once each month at a youth's place of residence.
One of three open independent living youth records reviewed did not show
documentation that face-to-face contact occurred with the youth who resides out of
state, for December 2024, January, February and March 2025, or June and
September 2025. The youth's refusal to consistently cooperate, a denial by
interstate compact to approve courtesy supervision, and the court's refusal to
dismiss the youth’s case were reported barriers in achieving this matter.
CPA Rule 400.12507 Medical, dental and mental health care.
(1) An agency shall ensure that a youth in independent living receives any needed
medical, dental, and mental health care as required in R 400.12413. Medical,
dental, and mental health care provided must be documented in the youth's record.
One of three independent living youth records reviewed did not show a medical
exam since 5/2/2024 or dental exam since 6/26/2024.
Repeat Violation Established:
Renewal 2024, CAP approved 11/6/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12509 Independent living record.
(3) The case record must contain all the following information and documentation,
which must be recorded within 30 calendar days after placement in independent
living and updated at least once every 90 calendar days:
(o) Service plans as required in R 400.12419 and R 400.12420. If the youth has
biological children, the service plan must address the living arrangement for the
child or children, visitation/parenting time with the youth's biological children or a
clear explanation why this is not possible or appropriate.
Two of three open independent living youth records reviewed did not show
documentation that all treatment plans were signed or signed timely by the youth.
CPA Rule 400.12510 Independent living agreement.
7

(2) The agreement must be signed and dated by the youth and the social service
worker. The agreement must be reviewed with the youth at least once every 90
calendar days and a copy provided to the youth.
One of three open independent living youth records reviewed did not show
consistent documentation of quarterly agreements signed by the youth, and the
worker; several were either missing or were not signed by the youth.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas.
• R400.12511(1)(b) Termination: The agency was apprised its termination
documentation shall consistently show the youth’s new location.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
• R400.12422(3)(d) & R400.12511(1)(d) Termination: The agency was
advised that ensuring that all sections of the action summary (DHS-69) it
utilizes to document information for the rule, is not left blank, may aid in
showing consistent compliance to the rule.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted one corrective plan during this reporting period under
review. The corrective action plan related to the agency’s 2024 renewal inspection
where it received 22 rule violations, where 7 were repeat violations. During this
2025 Interim inspection the agency received 19 rule violations and 10 are repeat
violations from 2024. The agency compliance around the 10 is as follows: the
number of individual cases cited decreased for 7 of these rules:( R400.12405(5)(a)
&(b) from 6 of 6, to 1 of 4; R400.12417(1)(c) -(g) from 3 of 6 to 2 of 6). The
number of individual cases cited remained the same for the other 3 rules:
R400.12413(1)(d) being 1 of 6; R400.12419(1)(c) being 2 of 6; and R400.12507(1)
being 1 of 3).
The agency implemented all action steps within its 2024 corrective action plan.
The agency reported the corrective action plan was helpful. They continue
efforts to have staff understand and to comply with all rules.
8

Chief Administrator Assessment
The agency submitted a chief administrator's report dated 10/15/2025(signed
8/22/25). The chief administrator (CA) reported on the prior year's inspection
violations, and the action steps it put in place to achieve compliance. The CA
reported the main barrier impacting compliance over the past review period was
supervisory staffing changes due to retirements, medical leave of absences, and
staff changes from the local office to a central location. Washtenaw was allowed to
borrow a supervisor from another County to assist, which was helpful, as the staff
person did a fantastic job. The CA further reported that their focus on the
corrective action plan was regularly with the foster care and licensing staff.
Additionally, the staff and supervisors utilized the CAP as a tool; and having the
corrective action plan as a standing agenda item for their foster care monthly
program meeting helped the foster care staff implement compliance around the
cited areas. The CA indicated the corrective action plan activities that had a
positive impact was licensing and foster care supervisors meeting regularly with
staff to review the items cited. The agency indicated a plan to continue to work
toward compliance in all areas; and to continue to education its staff around all
areas, with focus on repeat citations and missed information.
Financial Overview
Not applicable
Staff Interviews
In addition to a discussion with the chief administrator, section manager, and two
supervisors during the entrance conference, two foster care workers and one
licensing worker were interviewed. The staff interviewed reported various
strengths and attributes for the agency; which included supportive upper
management, team support; the administrators understanding workers’ stress and
personal issues and giving emotional support; and the district manager stepping in
to help when needed. Areas of need reported included gaining more staff; case
assistance with uploading documents; offering uber services to clients to help
them with their transportation needs; streamlining and decreasing some
checklists; safety discussions; more discussions around when a child from a
worker’s caseload is replaced from a foster home to a shelter; and supervisors
working together more as a unified team.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A walk through the agency's office did not reveal any areas of concern. There was
sufficient space and equipment for employees, and files were properly secured
and stored.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There was one safety alert identified.
Safety Alert: The Division of Child Welfare Licensing (DCWL) Analyst made
attempts to connect with the caregiver on 7/16/2025 and 7/30/2025. After no reply
from the caregiver, the Analyst reached out to the agency as the safety of the child
9

and the caregiver’s home could not be assessed
Resolution: The agency worker made a home visit to the home on 8/4/2025 and the
safety of the child and the home was verified. The worker also discussed with the
caregiver the importance of returning the DCWL Analyst’s calls. The child was also
seen on 8/6/2025 for parenting time and the child’s well-being was again confirmed.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
October 31,2025
________________________________________
Lonia Perry Calloway Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
October 31, 2025
________________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
10
